title: Monday, 19th November 2018
bodyHTML:
11:07 am
BE11:07am

Off we go then. Good morning. Hi. Welcome.

Blank canvas hi
Soundbuy Morning
wayneJ Morning
BE11:08am

Here's the picture to start us off.

BE11:08am

Manxish Morning everyone
11:08 am
BE11:08am

Mr Ghosn's lunch with the FT back in June.

BE11:08am

https://www.ft.com...-92d3-6c13e5c92914

Lawro Did he pay for at least with the spare cash he generated?
Lawro it*
BE11:09am

11:08 am
BE11:09am

And the FT picked up the tab.

BE11:10am

As chief executive and chairman of the alliance, Ghosn is one of the best-paid leaders in his industry. He earned €15m in 2016 from Renault and Nissan. His remuneration has drawn the ire of the French government, a major shareholder.

“Compensation is more scrutinised today than in the past — I have a lot of that . . . and there are lots of questions about what you are doing for society. But this doesn’t translate into less demand on performance . . . CEOs have to absolutely perform on the basic scorecard — growth, profit, free cash.”

Has it ever occurred to him that he is paid too much? “You won’t have any CEO say, ‘I’m overly compensated’,” he laughs. “It’s not up to me, the board is sovereign on this.”

BE11:10am

Hm.

tonyb Morning - Ghosn: what kind of figures are we talking about here?
alewis2005 >And the FT picked up the tab.This isn't really a bone to be picking - the FT always picks up the tab for LwtFT
11:11 am
BE11:11am

So this morning we get reports that he might be arrested, possibly for understating his salary.

BE11:12am

(@alewis2005: it wasn't a bone, jeez.)

BE11:12am

Which I think is Japanese for tax evasion.

wayneJ Is this a criminal or a civil offense in Japan? And what is the magnitude of the discrepancy?
IslandDweller AP says (on twitter) that he has been arrested
Mouselet Good morning. I do slightly wonder whether the Nissan/Renault thing is a coup against the weird Europeans on the board
Soundbuy 58 euro for the asparagus - guessing they had a crate between them.........
11:12 am
BE11:13am

And Nissan's moved to boot him out, with a reference to misusing company assets.

BE11:13am

https://www.ft.com...-8180-9cf212677a57

tonyb hehe
BE11:13am

What this means tor Renault is rather more complicated.

Mouselet ( Japan is notorious for CEO salaries very low by European standards )
IslandDweller Reuters also tweeted that he HAS been arrested
11:13 am
BE11:14am

Because it was already trading at nearly nothing.

BE11:14am

Here's Citi.

BE11:14am

The initial share price reaction
shows how pivotal he is for any potential collapse of the Renault-Nissan structure.
When asked about the structure of the Alliance at the Renault CMD in 2017, the
CEO said that concern about the longevity of the Alliance is a ‘temporary impediment to the Renault share price’ and that they were seeking a ‘solution’.

11:14 am
BE11:15am

The stub trades at a 50% discount to history. Core Renault (excluding stakes inc. Nissan) trades on an implied P/E of 3.2x (or a 50% discount to its 10 year average). This assumes a 25% hold-co discount. In the event that Ghosn does not return we would not be surprised for this discount to rise (given he is viewed as the chief architect of any solution).

Shinshin Nissault has a couple of corporate jets. So I guess it's the usual "we can always find an unapproved flight if we look hard enough" thing.
Mouselet soundbuy : eight spears for 29 euros
BE11:15am

We think Renault has the best set-up in the face of significant industry change. Its long-lasting alliance with Nissan has enabled it to generate material synergies and make significant progress in developing EVs (where it
seems to be ahead of peers in reaching profitability). The contract-manufacturing
agreement and open sourcing allows the company to leverage its investments more
than it could do with its own brand alone, in our view. It also enjoys sizeable exposure to EM-ex China, which to our minds are the markets offering the greatest growth potential in the coming years. The core-Renault business (ex-Nissan) generates sufficient free-cash flow to pay its dividend (30% payout) and also receives a sizeable dividend from its stake in Nissan. We are Buyers of the stock.

sprout Bbg saying 5Bn yen under-reported over five years.
Blank canvas but it's white asparagus which has a very short growing season. worth every penny i'd say
Shinshin Looks like he has finally taken one step too far with the Japanese establihment. Nice guy in person though (former neighbour).
wayneJ Clearly he should have commuted between France and Japan weekly uses the cheapest flights possible and paid for them personally.
BE11:16am

And Macquarie.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

We believe that the Alliance has already been moving to prepare organizationally for the “post-Ghosn” period, should it be precipitated by these events. We believe a robust cross-structure of joint operations is in place that the Alliance will continue to work together even without Mr. Ghosn at the helm. The current need for scale in the automotive world due to large-scale investments in electrification, connectivity and autonomous driving necessitates the need for the Alliance more than ever.

tadam So the Japanese want to put the French on ice using good old practices.
Mouselet so that's eight million euro a year, which is about half his disclosed salary
Soundbuy @ Mouselet.........hmmmm..................not the easiest thing to grow I guess.........
sprout Renault trading now on 3.5x 2018 P/E. Wow.
BE11:18am

But it also does a bit of compare and contrast.

BE11:18am

So Akio Toyoda, president of Toyota, earned ¥380m. Toyota Executive Vice President and Chairman of Toyota Motor Europe Didier
Leroy brought in ¥1.026bn.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

And the three Alliance members totalled ¥1.9bn for 2017.

BE11:19am

That's as per: https://www.asahi....ml?iref=pc_extlink

BE11:19am

They're buyers of Mitsubishi on weakness, FWIW.

Mouselet Mid-June's quite late in the white asparagus season
11:19 am
BE11:20am

Sorry, not Mitsu. Nissan. Can't read.

BE11:20am

While we prefer other automakers over Nissan (including Alliance member Mitsubishi Motors (7211 JP, ¥731, Outperform, TP: ¥960)), we believe Nissan
has in place a plan to revive profitability over the next few years that justifies a higher share price. We believe the dividend is secure at current levels. Any weakness would be a buying opportunity, as the possible end of the Ghosn era would not impact the company’s prospects nor those of the Alliance in our view.

FJ No other numbers tampered with?
pancakes or waffles for whoever was asking earlier -Gearoid Reidy Tokyo Deputy Bureau Chief GearoidReidy"Kyodo reporting that Ghosn is suspected of understating income by 5 billion yen over 5 years -- that's $44 million."Taken from BBG's live blog
cheeckychappy So were are talking white asparagus now...
Mouselet So Asahi is saying that he was paid about a billion yen, and the lunch-with-the-FT gives a salary equivalent to two billion yen. Does Japan want to tax worldwide income?
wayneJ Is this actual fraud or is it an issue of resident / non-resident ---- ie he has assumed that paying tax in France on his Renault salary means he does not need to declare in Japan? Also I assume he uses some serious accountants to file his tax returns?
BE11:23am

Wonder if we'll get the big page type articles drawing a line between Ghosn and Sorrell by the end of the day? Maybe restart the stuff about a corporate equivalent to a Twenty-Second Amendment?

Soundbuy @cheeckychappy..............at 29 euro a pop they come in any colour you want.........
Shinshin Japan has a owrldwide income kicker for non-nationals at certain lengths of residence. So if he was technically residnet due to days in/out then he would be liable for offshore comp. But his accountants need to have a word with themsleves.
FATDAZ Perhaps I have misunderstood but shouldn't the renumeration committee and HR departments of Renault / Nissan have known what MR Ghon was paid?
11:23 am
BE11:24am

It's certainly in safer legal territory than some of the ROTR are yomping into right now.

undefined
cheeckychappy Any DPL?
Mouselet My apologies. Asparagus also comes in purple.
FATDAZ And would nt those figures be reported annually?
BE11:24am

Having said that, what else to do?

cheeckychappy Foxtons steady at 50p
11:25 am
BE11:25am

There's Johnston Press, bowing to the inevitable.

Johnston Press PLC (JPR:LSE): Last: 2.75, no change, Volume: 0.00
StandupComedianTurnedHFAnalyst anything shaking out in the bond world?
BE11:26am

That value should of course read zero. They're done.

Mouselet https://www.theguardian.com/money/2018/nov/19/uk-house-prices-fall-5000-brexit-south-november-rightmove is presumably the DPL
11:26 am
BE11:26am

Assets to be hermit crabbed into JPI Media via a pre-pack administration

BE11:27am

So you end up with the Yorkshire Post being owned by Goldentree Asset Management, Fidelity, Caravel Asset Management and Benefits Street Partners.

BE11:27am

https://www.ft.com...-8180-9cf212677a57

FATDAZ @standup saw a comment that suggests Dutch are not keen on post Brexit pan EU budget
Dec69 - Skeptic last time I had lunch with the FT I got a burger, sheesh, I'm a cheap date!
11:28 am
BE11:28am

And it seems likely that the pension fund -- which has a £40m deficit -- will be picked up by the Pension Protection Fund.

FATDAZ Lol
BE11:28am

Which has already worn Carillion

cheeckychappy Mmmmmmm - Benefits Street Partners....????
cheeckychappy @Mouselet - cheers. So not much changed then...
FATDAZ We need to prevent pension funds becoming underfunded rather than pickkng up the tab post the event
Maverick Morning Bryce, having read a very interesting and recent article from your team with regards to ITV I did just wonder if it is a story you are still chasing?Many thanks in advance
BE11:30am

One can grumble about whether the funds should've also worn the pension liabilities, rather than the high likelihood of them falling to the state. But, hey, newspapers.

11:30 am
undefined
cheeckychappy Who do these vulture funds want to own newspapers? Weird...
Mouselet Don't tell me, the PPF is not funded by a levy which scales automatically based on the amount it's had to pay out in the past
BE11:31am

@Maverick..... nope. We have nothing whatsoever on ITV. We didn't last week either as far as I know.

Shinshin @cheeky Johnstone was operationally profitable I think. It was the debt load which killed it.
cheeckychappy Also - what was that Scandi punter playing at with Johnston Press...?
BE11:32am

As for house prices. They're down. As in asking prices. First time year on year since 2011. It's thrilling.

Maverick Okay, nice one, cheers
StandupComedianTurnedHFAnalyst i think those funds are stuck in it. No one really thinks they will make money of a printing press in yorkshire
Pharma @Shinshin without my mortgage I am operationally profitable. Should I get in touch with these funds to discuss a deal?
Shinshin And this PPF loophole for pre-pack is surely going to get plugged just as soon as there is a functioning government available.
11:32 am
Barratt Developments PLC (BDEV:LSE): Last: 497.90, down 5.1 (-1.01%), High: 503.60, Low: 487.30, Volume: 1.47m
cheeckychappy @pharma - LOL
Persimmon PLC (PSN:LSE): Last: 2,119, down 9 (-0.42%), High: 2,147, Low: 2,089, Volume: 438.43k
Shinshin @pharma Is your pension fund also in deficit ?
BE11:34am

Course, house prices are irrelevant to the housebuilders, who like retired newspapermen now exist largely on state subsidies.

StandupComedianTurnedHFAnalyst @pharma - they will divide you up and sell parts - you are worth more in bits than in whole
11:34 am
BE11:34am

And like retired newspapermen do nothing useful for the money.

Mouselet 'A great opportunity to acquire a lock-up garage in a popular residential area of Saffron Walden'
cheeckychappy Johnston Press probably a good demonstration for the newspaper industry that consolidation to achieve cost cutting doesn't really get you anywhere unless you have proper plan to achieve revenue growth elsewhere somehow...
BE11:35am

It is, however, a good excuse to share JPM's "keep avoiding the UK" thing.

wayneJ @Shinshin - completely agree - the Pension regulator appears to be sleeping.....we need Frank Field on the case
BE11:35am

[BREXIT]

cheeckychappy @Bryce - what's the latest on Brexit...
11:36 am
BE11:36am

We have argued that one should continue to stay away from the UK Domestic names – Banks, Homebuilders, Property and Retail – because even when the UK gets the deal from the EU, the likelihood that it passes in the UK parliament will initially look quite slim. The bounce in UK Domestic stocks seen in September-October has faded, and we expect new relative lows for the group, and potentially a new low in GBP/USD, before the eventual bottoming out.

StandupComedianTurnedHFAnalyst They should have handed over the company to the pensioners - they likely had the fulcrum security anyway
BE11:36am

What comes next? The proposed deal will go to the parliament for a vote over the next 2-3 weeks, but we expect it to fail, at least the first time around. The number of MPs who are likely to record their “protest vote” against Prime Minister Theresa May
looks too high. The deal is then likely to be returned to the EU for any amendments, but the EU is unlikely to revise the original offer.

wayneJ Also what is the liability of the board for the pensions and ditto for the equity investors. Surely a debt for equity swap with the listed entity was the best way?
BE11:37am

Therefore, the eventual passing of the deal, probably sometime between mid-December and mid-January, will largely depend on things getting significantly worse from here in order for enough of rebel MPs to fall back in line. This path has understandably very large tail risks, and is likely to flirt with any and all of the following along the way: No-Deal, leadership challenge and new elections. In case of new elections, the prospect of a Labour government becomes material. A month ahead of the last elections, Labour was trailing Conservatives by almost 15% in polls, but still managed to get within 3% on the Election Day. Currently, the gap is lower than 5%.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

We believe that if any of these tail risks start to look more likely, UK Domestic basket – JPDEUKDM, chiefly comprised of Homebuilders, Real Estate, Banks and Retail names, will sell-off further. Also, while typically a weaker GBP tends to help UK equities, we worry that the traditional inverse GBP/UKX correlation might break down in case of further FX falls

BE11:38am

JPM's indexes have domestics down 26% vs exporters

BE11:38am

And at a 3% P/E discount to historical averages

FATDAZ Does nt Theresa May face an issue with passing the finance bill through parliament well before the Brexit bill?
11:38 am
BE11:38am

Whereas the exporters are at a 5% P/E premium vs historical norms

IslandDweller @Fatdaz. She does. but I have spent the last year saying "she can't survive" and yet somehow she does
BE11:39am

And earnings expectations are already pretty realistic in the event of a deal, says JPM. 3% for domestics, 8% for exporters

BE11:40am

However, if tail risks become the base case, the downside can still be very material. UK Domestic stocks tended to show 40-50% relative EPS falls in previous UK growth downturns, with trough valuation multiples lower than current. Their current earnings are still near the cycle peak. Given this, we would look to buy the Domestic stocks once the deal starts to appear secured, as then the GBP will likely be also bouncing, but not before. For now, while the tail risks stay uncomfortably high, we remain OW UK Exporters vs Domestic, and FTSE100 vs FTSE250.

FATDAZ At Island Dweller fair point
wayneJ Pls, pls, pls......will someone stop Mrs May spouting that we are growing faster outside the EU........isn't it a reflection of EU signing FTA with other countries.....FTAs that the new UK will not be able to access
11:40 am
undefined
wayneJ Also will someone ask her about the tax impact of Brexit. I have been doing some back of the envelope and it is easy to get into high single digit %/ low double digit % impact
wayneJ And (sorry on a rant) what is the impact on the equity risk premium for the entire country?
Flowerpotman @waynej See Gavin Davis column
BE11:42am

Hm ...... Still 20 minutes to go and, like, no damn news (apart from Ghosn).

Manxish @wayneJ - i think the ship has long since sailed on getting politicians of all ilks to stop misrepresenting simple facts, unfortunately
Soundbuy Diploma?
BE11:43am

So .... let's head off into a cul de sac.

11:43 am

11:45 am

hornblower Debs bounce a bit of short covering?

... the bull is that Ashley has a deep understanding of retail that means he can reinvigorate the big barn shops

Use Flannels or whatever to supply the upscale, put a gaming arena in the basement, etc ......

... and then there's the bear argument, which tends to be the dominant one for anyone who's actually been into one of his shops.

Pharma Maybe that's what House of Fraser has always looked like. Anyone here been in one before? Anyone??
BE11:50am

Ashley can't cope with fallow floorspace. Everything's filled up with whatever he can find. No time for refits.

BornCynic @Pharma - Guilty. I did not buy anything.........
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian If you follow JPM's advice by the time things look good it will be too late to buy. Buy now and ignore the so-called professionals. Most of them are kids and don't know any better than you.
Lemmy is he skilful? Or just buying a truck load of stock on the cheap? (buying low and selling high is a different skill, often overlooked)
11:50 am

So you end up with SoulCal & Co next to the Armani.

BE11:51am

BE11:52am

How pleased will Armani be at that? Not very I'd imagine.

StandupComedianTurnedHFAnalyst at least describe the photos
wayneJ In essence, BE, aren't u saying that he is underinvested in the stores so he is currently 'overearning'? Must admit that we spent some time this weekend buying sportwear - barely 3% of the spend ended up in SportsDirect. Very surprising how many specialist sports shops once u start looking - even in a medium sized town.
Soundbuy Lack of customers in your pics.....
11:52 am
BE11:52am

Meaning, suppliers will cut them off and House of Fraser will gradually turn into giant untidy Sports Directs.

hornblower @ 1st Lt - agree, I don't think you can wait until the risks are resolved and still have the chance to buy cheap
Soundbuy @StandupComedianTurnedHFAnalyst - simply Bryce head-to-toe in Lonsdale...

Full of third-tier stuff from the brands and a heap of Firetrap etc.

wayneJ Also wife decided I needed new clothes. Surprised at pricing at M&S - much much cheaper than I ever remember it. (Got one T-shirt for 56p - though the stand had said £4. Even the staff could not believe it).
Lemmy Looks like a TK Maxx pop-up
BE11:53am

Exactly how Lillywhites is right now, in essence. They'll turn Jenners in to Lillywhites.

Mouselet Do you not feel that customers are sufficiently used to the random-adjacent-stuff experience from Internet searching that they don't mind it in reality as much as high-end stuff-makers think they will?
11:53 am
BE11:54am

And Edinburgh will revolt.

undefined
wayneJ Ashley's risk is balance sheet / credit insurance. Especially as not clarity as to what has Sport Direct parent guarantees and what not?

Well, that killed a few minutes. What else?

11:54 am
BE11:54am

Diploma mentioned.

Soundbuy Should be a weekly slot........'out and about with Bryce'............

Diploma PLC (DPLM:LSE): Last: 1,368, up 72.5 (+5.60%), High: 1,400, Low: 1,266, Volume: 128.72k
BE11:56am

Trading statement's fine. Still doesn't have a CEO but that's not holding it back.

11:56 am
BE11:56am

Numbers much as expected post the August update, outlook reassuring.

Shinshin @wayne nub of M+S problem, no ? Not cheap enough to compete with Primark, not good enough to compete with Ted Baker / Paul Smith etc
wayneJ Mrs May just finished her speech. Why has every politician since the 1970s talked about a high wage economy with improved skills / training blah blah blah

Cash building up to support another big acquisition once they have someone to sign the cheque.

BE11:57am

Here's Peel Hunt.

Mouselet Because talking about a low-wage economy where minions do unskilled things for no money makes politicians and voters alike depressed?
11:57 am
BE11:57am

FY18 revenue was +7%, with Seals the best performing division +10%, and operating margins +20bps to 17.5%, resulting in a small beat of 2% vs our adj PBT estimate. The statement reads well, with the board confident of further progress next year despite the wider macro-economic uncertainty, and we are upgrading our FY19E profit forecasts by 2% in accordance with the FY18 beat. This is a solid set of results, especially considering the board has been preoccupied for several months with the search for a new CEO, and again demonstrates the quality of the business. We reiterate our Add recommendation and 1,400p target price.

wayneJ @Shishin - I partially agree with you. But I also find that some stores are 'hostile' to anyone over about 30 years of age. Simple example - I was recently at a fruity store looking to acquire a new mobile handset device - the sales woman insisted on putting a speaker on full volume and gyrating whilst I was trying to speak to her.
BE11:58am

Against that, they're expensive.

BE11:58am

Stifel:

11:58 am
BE11:58am

Shares trading on FY19 PER of 21x which is top of the range for our industrial
distribution peer group and leaves little room for error.

Mouselet Often the fruity stores have a variety of sales minions some of whom are of an older, calmer and less gyratory disposition
BE11:59am

And Barclays:

BE11:59am

Outlook reports that “despite the global macro-economic uncertainty, the Board remains confident that the Group will continue to make further progress in the coming year” – after an unusually strong couple of years for organic growth, the progress expected in FY19 may well shift back towards a larger contribution from M&A given management’s comment in the statement that “there were tentative signs towards the end of the year” that the challenging environment for M&A was easing. DPLM trades on a CY2019 PE of 21.4x and EV/EBITA of 15.1x.

wayneJ Whilst at least at John Lewis and M&S the staff speak in English, pay attention and the musak does not deafen u. Oh, and they usually have a range of sizes and styles / cuts etc
alewis2005 >fruity stores:o
Tom Dalgleish Never groove with a sales assistant
11:59 am
undefined

wayneJ When I pointed out that I had invested over the years in private co.s that had sold to the fruity co and might know what I am talking about she got more stroppy etc.

Soundbuy Cheers all.........

12:02 pm
